content.text: Once upon a time, in a quiet little village nestled between rolling green hills, there lived a kind woodcutter and his gentle wife.
They had seven sons, each as lively as the next, but no daughter to complete their happy home.
At last, after many years of hoping, the wife gave birth to a tiny, delicate baby girl.
She was so small and frail that her parents feared for her life, and in their worry, they decided to baptize her at once, lest anything should happen to her before the ceremony.
The woodcutter sent one of his sons to fetch water from the well for the baptism, but in their haste, the seven brothers all rushed to help.
As they drew the water, the pitcher slipped from their hands and fell into the well with a great splash.
The brothers stood frozen, not knowing what to do.
They dared not return home without the water, for their father would be angry, and their little sister would go unbaptized.
In their fear, the eldest brother cried, "Let us fly away before Father scolds us!" And so, with a wave of his hand, he turned himself and his six brothers into seven black ravens.
With a great flapping of wings, they soared into the sky and vanished over the treetops.
Meanwhile, the woodcutter and his wife waited and waited for their sons to return.
When they did not come back, the father grew furious. "Those careless boys!" he shouted.
"They have ruined everything!" But as the hours passed, his anger turned to sorrow, and he wept for his lost sons.
The baby girl, however, grew stronger with each passing day.
She was a sweet and cheerful child, and though her parents never spoke of her brothers, she often wondered why she had none.
Years went by, and the girl grew into a kind and beautiful young maiden.
One day, she overheard her parents talking in hushed tones.
"If only our sons had not been so foolish," her mother sighed.
"They would have been here to see their sister grow up." The girl’s heart ached with curiosity.
"Mother," she asked, "did I once have brothers?" Her parents hesitated, but at last, they told her the whole story—the seven ravens, the lost pitcher, and the magic that had taken them away.
The girl’s eyes filled with tears. "I must find them," she declared.
"I must bring my brothers home." Her parents begged her not to go, for the world was vast and full of dangers, but she would not be swayed.
That very night, she packed a small bundle with a loaf of bread, a jug of water, and a tiny golden ring that had belonged to her mother.
Then, with a brave heart, she set off on her journey.
She walked for many days, through dark forests and over high mountains, asking everyone she met if they had seen seven ravens.
But no one could help her.
At last, she came to a great, gloomy castle perched atop a jagged cliff.
The wind howled around its towers, and the gates were locked tight.
The girl knocked and called out, but no one answered.
Just as she was about to turn away, she heard a faint voice from above.
"Who is there?" it asked. "I am a maiden searching for my seven brothers, the ravens," she replied.
"Have you seen them?"  The voice grew sad. "They live here, but they are under a terrible spell.
Only a sister’s love can break it.
If you wish to enter, you must first pass three trials."  The girl swallowed hard but nodded.
"I will do whatever it takes."  The first trial was a room filled with bones.
The voice instructed her to gather them and arrange them into seven skeletons.
Though her hands trembled, she did as she was told, and when she had finished, the bones turned into seven sleeping ravens.
The second trial was a room filled with feathers.
The voice told her to weave the feathers into seven cloaks, one for each raven.
The girl worked tirelessly, her fingers sore and bleeding, but at last, the cloaks were complete.
The third trial was the hardest of all.
The voice led her to a well and told her to fill a golden cup with water from its depths.
But the well was bottomless, and no matter how hard she tried, the cup remained empty.
Just as she was about to give up, a tiny white dove fluttered down and dropped a single golden key into her hand.
"Use this," the dove whispered.
The girl took the key and unlocked a hidden door at the base of the well.
Inside, she found a small pool of water. She filled the cup and returned it to the voice.
At last, the trials were over.
The voice told her to enter the castle’s great hall, where the seven ravens sat around a table, their black feathers ruffled and their eyes downcast.
The girl stepped forward and placed the golden ring upon the table.
"Brothers," she said softly, "I have come to bring you home."  The ravens stared at her in wonder.
Then, one by one, they began to change. Their feathers fell away, and their wings shrank into arms.
Before her stood seven young men, her brothers, just as they had been before the spell.
They embraced her, weeping with joy, and thanked her for her courage.
Together, they returned to their parents’ home, where the woodcutter and his wife wept with happiness to see their sons again.
The little sister, who had once been so frail, had grown into a brave and loving young woman.
And from that day forward, the family lived together in peace, their hearts full of gratitude for the magic of love and the bonds that could never be broken.
